verses.text: Then the heads of the fathers’ houses of the Levites came to Eleazar the priest, to Joshua the son of Nun, and to the heads of the fathers’ houses of the tribes of the children of Israel.
verses.comment: This verse sets the scene for the giving of Levitical cities, fulfilling God’s command to provide for the priestly tribe (see Num. 35:2). The Levites' special election points toward the pattern of priestly mediation between God and His people—fulfilled perfectly in Christ, the High Priest (Heb. 4:14).

verses.text: And they spoke to them at Shiloh in the land of Canaan, saying, 'The LORD commanded through Moses to give us cities to live in, along with their pasturelands for our livestock.'
verses.comment: Shiloh is highlighted as the religious center (- see Josh. 18:1). The Levites’ request is the fulfillment of God’s covenant promise by divine command – an example of orderly worship and obedience.

verses.text: So by the command of the LORD, the Israelites gave to the Levites out of their inheritance, these cities and their pasturelands.
verses.comment: The entire nation’s obedience to God’s command in providing for the Levites reflects a spirit of unity and common purpose in the one people of God.

verses.text: The lot came out for the families of the Kohathites. So the Levites, who were descendants of Aaron the priest, received by lot thirteen cities from the tribes of Judah, Simeon, and Benjamin.
verses.comment: Aaron’s line is singled out as priests, foreshadowing Christ as the true High Priest (Heb. 5:1-10). The use of lots shows God’s providential guidance for the leaders of His people.

verses.text: The rest of the Kohathites received ten cities by lot from the families of the tribes of Ephraim, Dan, and the half-tribe of Manasseh.
verses.comment: God provides for the entirety of the priestly families, showing His care for all His ministers—an image of the Church’s care for those set apart for service (1 Tim. 5:17).

verses.text: The Gershonites received thirteen cities by lot from the families of the tribes of Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and the half-tribe of Manasseh in Bashan.
verses.comment: Each Levitical division, though different, has a necessary role—foreshadowing the unity of diverse gifts in the Body of Christ (1 Cor. 12:12-27).

verses.text: The Merarites by their families received twelve cities from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and Zebulun.
verses.comment: No tribe is left unrepresented in supporting the Levites, emphasizing shared participation in the life and worship of God’s people.

verses.text: The Israelites assigned these cities with their pasturelands by lot to the Levites, just as the LORD had commanded through Moses.
verses.comment: Israel’s obedience ensures the Levitical ministry can continue. God’s unbroken promises to His chosen people prefigure the security of God’s covenant today (Luke 1:72-75).

verses.text: From the tribes of Judah and Simeon, they gave the cities listed below.
verses.comment: These lists were preserved for reference, pointing to the importance of order and historical memory within the faith community.

verses.text: These were for the descendants of Aaron of the families of the Kohathites, of the Levites, for theirs was the first lot.
verses.comment: The order of lots illustrates the special distinction given to the priestly line of Aaron.

verses.text: They gave them Kiriath Arba (that is, Hebron), in the hill country of Judah, with its surrounding pasturelands. (Arba was the father of Anak.)
verses.comment: Hebron’s significance (as Abraham’s resting place) underlines the connection with the patriarchs and the continuity of faith.

verses.text: But the fields of the city and its villages they gave to Caleb the son of Jephunneh as his possession.
verses.comment: Caleb’s faithfulness is rewarded (Josh. 14:13-14); the dividing of land reinforces the concept of spiritual inheritance for the faithful.

verses.text: To the descendants of Aaron the priest they gave Hebron, the city of refuge for the slayer, with its pasturelands, Libnah with its pasturelands,
verses.comment: Hebron’s role as a city of refuge is a powerful type of the mercy to be found in Christ—the true Refuge (Heb. 6:18).

verses.text: Jattir with its pasturelands, Eshtemoa with its pasturelands,
verses.comment: These assigned cities continue the theme of God providing for the needs of His ministers, inviting reflection on our own duty to support those set apart for holy service.

verses.text: Holon with its pasturelands, Debir with its pasturelands,
Ain with its pasturelands, Juttah with its pasturelands, and Beth Shemesh with its pasturelands—nine cities from these two tribes.
verses.comment: Beth Shemesh, later a major Levitical city where the Ark was kept, has deep connections with the priestly ministry and worship.

verses.text: From the tribe of Benjamin, Gibeon with its pasturelands, Geba with its pasturelands,
Anathoth with its pasturelands, and Almon with its pasturelands—four cities.
verses.comment: Anathoth would later be the home of the prophet Jeremiah, showing the enduring spiritual legacy of the Levitical cities.

verses.text: All the cities of the descendants of Aaron, the priests, numbered thirteen cities with their pasturelands.
verses.comment: Accurate enumeration here also reflects faithfulness in accounting for the stewardship of God’s gifts.

verses.text: The other families of the Kohathites, the Levites, received cities by lot from the tribe of Ephraim.
They gave them Shechem, the city of refuge for the slayer, with its pasturelands in the hill country of Ephraim, Gezer with its pasturelands,
verses.comment: Shechem, like Hebron, is another city of refuge—a foretaste of God’s ultimate mercy, seen in the role of Christ as our refuge (Heb. 6:18).

verses.text: Kibzaim with its pasturelands, and Beth Horon with its pasturelands—four cities.
From the tribe of Dan, Elteke with its pasturelands, Gibbethon with its pasturelands,
Aijalon with its pasturelands, and Gath Rimmon with its pasturelands—four cities.
From the half-tribe of Manasseh, Taanach with its pasturelands and Gath Rimmon with its pasturelands—two cities.
All ten cities and their pasturelands were for the families of the rest of the Kohathite Levites.

To the Gershonites, one of the families of the Levites, from the half-tribe of Manasseh: Golan in Bashan, the city of refuge for the slayer, with its pasturelands, and Be Eshterah with its pasturelands—two cities.
verses.comment: Again, another city of refuge. The presence of sanctuary cities in every region shows God’s mercy available to all Israel—unitive and universal.

verses.text: From the tribe of Issachar: Kishion with its pasturelands, Daberath with its pasturelands,
Jarmuth with its pasturelands, and En Gannim with its pasturelands—four cities.
From the tribe of Asher: Mishal with its pasturelands, Abdon with its pasturelands,
Helkath with its pasturelands, and Rehob with its pasturelands—four cities.
From the tribe of Naphtali: Kedesh in Galilee, the city of refuge for the slayer, with its pasturelands, Hammoth Dor with its pasturelands, and Kartan with its pasturelands—three cities.
verses.comment: Kedesh’s repeated mention as a city of refuge reminds us of God’s unchanging justice and mercy—fulfilled ultimately in Christ’s saving work.

verses.text: All the cities of the Gershonites according to their families were thirteen cities with their pasturelands.
To the families of the Merarite Levites, the rest of the Levites, from the tribe of Zebulun: Jokneam with its pasturelands, Kartah with its pasturelands,
Dimnah with its pasturelands, Nahalal with its pasturelands—four cities.
From the tribe of Reuben: Bezer with its pasturelands, Jahaz with its pasturelands,
verses.comment: Bezer as a city of refuge in Transjordan again illustrates God’s plan for justice and mercy to be accessible everywhere.

verses.text: Kedemoth with its pasturelands, and Mephaath with its pasturelands—four cities.
From the tribe of Gad: Ramoth in Gilead, the city of refuge for the slayer, with its pasturelands, Mahanaim with its pasturelands,
verses.comment: Ramoth-Gilead was a significant city of refuge east of the Jordan—further emphasizing the idea of sanctuary throughout all the people of God.

verses.text: Heshbon with its pasturelands, and Jazer with its pasturelands—four cities in all.
All these were the cities allotted to the families of the Merarite Levites, the rest of the Levites. According to their lot, their total was twelve cities.
All the cities of the Levites within the inheritance of the Israelites were forty-eight cities with their pasturelands.
verses.comment: The complete provision for the Levites reflects the wholeness and sufficiency of God’s care for His people.

verses.text: Each of these cities had its own pasturelands around it; so it was with all these cities.
verses.comment: This detail points to both practical sufficiency and the orderly way God’s worship was provided for.

verses.text: So the LORD gave to Israel all the land that he had sworn to give to their fathers. They took possession of it and lived in it.
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob is fulfilled here, foreshadowing the even greater fulfillment in Christ and the inheritance of all nations (see Gal. 3:29).

verses.text: And the LORD gave them rest on every side, just as he had sworn to their fathers. Not one of all their enemies withstood them, for the LORD gave all their enemies into their hands.
verses.comment: This theme of rest points ahead to the ultimate rest found in Christ—our peace and our inheritance in the new creation (Heb. 4:9).

verses.text: Not one word of all the good promises that the LORD had made to the house of Israel failed; all came to pass.
verses.comment: God’s faithfulness is absolute; His promises are trustworthy. In Christ, ALL God’s promises reach their fulfillment (2 Cor. 1:20).
